resources.string: Emergency Report has been sent. Help will arrive shortly.
Do you really want to report Emergency
Do you really want to report Emergency? False claims may lead to jurisdicial cases

Do's: 1. Avoid building in flood-prone areas without elevation and reinforcement. 2. Elevate furnace, water heater, and electric panel to prevent flood damage. 3. Install "Check Valves" in sewer traps to avoid drain backup. 4. Contact community officials about flood barriers in your area. 5. Seal basement walls with waterproofing compounds. If a flood is imminent: 6. Stay informed through radio or TV. 7. Move to higher ground immediately if flash flooding is possible. 8. Be cautious near flood-prone areas, even without typical rain warnings. Preparing to evacuate: 9. Secure your home and bring in outdoor furniture. 10. Turn off utilities as instructed, and disconnect electrical appliances. When leaving your home: 11. Avoid walking through moving water; it can make you fall. 12. Never drive into flooded areas; abandon your car and seek higher ground.

Do's: 1. Avoid building in fire-prone areas without proper precautions. 2. Elevate your home's fire safety by installing spark arresters on chimneys and stovepipes. 3. Keep firefighting tools nearby when working in dry, grassy areas, including a garden hose, buckets of water, or a fire extinguisher. 4. Store flammable materials such as firewood and propane at a safe distance from your home. 5. Develop a family emergency plan that includes escape routes and a designated meeting point. If a fire is imminent: 6. Monitor local news and weather reports for fire danger warnings. 7. Ensure your phone is charged and ready to receive emergency notifications. 8. If you receive an evacuation order, leave immediately and follow designated evacuation routes. Preparing to evacuate: 9. Pack essential items such as identification, medications, important documents, and clothing. 10. Turn off gas and electricity at the main switches or valves before leaving. 11. Close all windows and doors to prevent drafts. During evacuation: 12. Stay low to the ground if smoke is present; the air is cleaner near the floor. 13. Cover your nose and mouth with a cloth to filter out smoke and ash. 14. Do not return home until authorities declare it safe to do so. 15. Be cautious of fallen power lines and other hazards when returning to your property.

Do's: 1. Secure heavy furniture and objects to prevent them from toppling over during an earthquake. 2. Install earthquake-resistant bolts for your home's foundation and gas lines. 3. Create an emergency kit with essential supplies, including food, water, and first-aid items. 4. Develop a family emergency plan with communication and meeting points. 5. Know how to shut off gas, electricity, and water in your home. If an Earthquake Strikes: 6. Drop, Cover, and Hold On: Drop to the ground, take cover under a sturdy piece of furniture, and hold on until shaking stops. 7. Stay indoors: Avoid going outside during the shaking as falling debris can be dangerous. 8. If you are outside, move to an open area away from buildings, trees, streetlights, and utility wires. After the Shaking Stops: 9. Check for injuries and administer first aid as necessary. 10. Inspect your home for damage, especially gas leaks, electrical problems, and structural issues. If you smell gas, turn it off and leave your home. 11. Listen to emergency broadcasts for updates and instructions. 12. Avoid using the phone except for emergencies to keep lines open for first responders. Evacuation: 13. If your home is unsafe, follow evacuation orders and move to a safe location. 14. Use caution when driving, and be aware of road hazards, including fallen debris and damaged roads. 15. Stay informed and follow the guidance of local authorities for safety instructions.

Do's: 1. Secure outdoor objects and furniture to prevent them from becoming projectiles during a storm. 2. Reinforce windows and doors with storm shutters or impact-resistant glass. 3. Create an emergency kit with essential supplies, including non-perishable food, water, flashlights, and batteries. 4. Develop a family emergency plan with communication and meeting points. 5. Stay informed about storm warnings and updates through reliable sources like weather alerts and local authorities. If a Storm is Imminent: 6. Listen to weather alerts and follow the advice of local authorities. 7. Seek shelter in a safe location, away from windows and doors. 8. Stay indoors and avoid going outside during the storm, as flying debris and strong winds can be dangerous. After the Storm: 9. Check for injuries and provide first aid as needed. 10. Inspect your home for damage, including structural issues, gas leaks, and electrical problems. If you smell gas, turn it off and leave your home. 11. Use a flashlight to examine your surroundings; avoid using candles or open flames as there may be gas leaks or flammable materials present. 12. Listen to emergency broadcasts for updates and instructions. Evacuation: 13. If authorities issue evacuation orders, leave your home and follow designated evacuation routes to a safe location. 14. Be cautious while driving and watch for road hazards, including fallen trees and flooded areas. 15. Stay informed and adhere to the guidance of local authorities for safety precautions and instructions.

string.name: faq_1_question
string.b: What is the purpose of this application?

resources.string: This application is designed to help coordinate the efforts of rescue agencies during natural or man-made disasters, making it easier for them to provide aid effectively.
Rescue agencies and individuals in need of assistance can use this app. Rescue agencies can register their information, while individuals can request help.

string.name: faq_3_question
string.b: How do rescue agencies register on the app?

resources.string: Rescue agencies can register by providing their information, including location, contact details, and areas of expertise. They can do this manually or through automated GPS tracking.

string.name: faq_4_question
string.b: Is the app available on both Android and iOS devices?

resources.string: No, the app is currently available on Android only.

string.name: faq_5_question
string.b: Can individuals request help from rescue agencies through the app?

resources.string: Yes, individuals can use the app to send requests for assistance to nearby rescue agencies.

string.name: faq_6_question
string.b: How can I find rescue agencies in my area?

resources.string: You can search for rescue agencies by criteria such as location, expertise, available resources, and type of disaster response. The app also provides a map view with agency locations.

string.name: faq_7_question
string.b: Is my personal information safe when using the app?

resources.string: Yes, the app implements strong security measures to protect user data and agency information. It complies with privacy and data protection regulations.

string.name: faq_8_question
string.b: Can rescue agencies communicate and collaborate through the app?

resources.string: Yes, rescue agencies can send alerts, requests for assistance, and collaborate on shared resources directly through the app\'s messaging and communication features.

string.name: faq_9_question
string.b: How can I report issues or provide feedback about the app?

resources.string: You can report issues and provide feedback through the app\'s support or contact channels. Your input is valuable for improving the app.

string.name: faq_10_question
string.b: What should I do in case of an emergency?

resources.string: In case of an emergency, please call your local emergency services number. The app is designed to complement, not replace, existing emergency services.

string.name: faq_11_question
string.b: Can I volunteer with rescue agencies through the app?

resources.string: The app may provide information about volunteer opportunities with rescue agencies, but the actual volunteering process would typically be coordinated outside the app.

string.name: faq_13_question
string.b: How can I help improve disaster response in my community?

resources.string: By using the app and encouraging local rescue agencies to register, you can contribute to better disaster response and coordination in your community.

string.name: faq_14_question
string.b: Is the app free to download and use?

resources.string: Yes, the app is free to download and use for both rescue agencies and individuals.

string.name: faq_15_question
string.b: Are there any offline features for use in areas with limited connectivity during disasters?

resources.string: The app may include some offline features for basic functionality in areas with limited connectivity, but it primarily relies on an internet connection for real-time coordination.
